prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the AITA post is in the wrong. The situation is about a partner taking their 3-year-old out to a fun activity while the other partner is at work. The partner usually gives excuses when they want to go out, and this time the person went ahead without them. The partner is upset about it.

First, I need to break down the key points. The author mentions that their partner consistently makes excuses to not go out on weekends, like being tired, not wanting to drive, or not wanting to spend money. The author then arranged a trip with a friend when the partner was at work. The partner got upset, feeling it's unfair since they're working, and now wants to cancel so they can go another day. The author is arguing that they had tried before and been told no, so this time they just went ahead.

So, the main issue here is about shared responsibility in childcare and whether one parent can take the child out without the other. In many cases, parents do alternate taking the kids out, especially when one is unavailable. The partner's excuses might indicate a pattern of not wanting to participate in activities, which could be a red flag. But the author's action of going without the partner while they're at work could be seen as taking initiative to provide the child with an enriching experience.

But the partner's reaction is about fairness. They might feel left out or think that the author is dismissing their feelings. However, the author points out that previous requests were denied, so this is a way to ensure the child gets to go. The cost is low (7 pounds each), and the activity is a children's petting zoo, which isn't a big expense. The author isn't going to a movie alone, but a family activity with a friend.

Considering all that, the author isn't necessarily in the wrong. They took the initiative to provide an activity for the child when the other parent wasn't available and had previously been uncooperative. The partner's reaction might be about feeling excluded, but the author had valid reasons based on past behavior. So the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong.
